name: Chloe Bernstein
clarity_response: An app that gives you a short curated list of things to do in NYC instead of making you scroll through hundreds of options.
strongest_line: Stop scrolling six apps just to figure out what to do this weekend.
weakest_section: Social proof — the stats feel made up. '87% of people we interviewed' from 50 people isn't a real stat.
what_feels_off: The social proof stats from 50 interviews feel thin. Also 'built from conversations with 50+ New Yorkers' — that's not very many.
objections: I need to see it actually work before I join a waitlist. A waitlist for what, exactly? When does it launch?
gut_reaction: This speaks to me. The headline alone made me stop. But a waitlist with no launch date feels like it might never happen.
unanswered_questions: When does it launch? Is it an app or a website? Will it actually have enough events to be useful?
share_trigger: If I could show a friend the 3-5 recommendations in action, I'd share it immediately. The concept is shareable, the waitlist is not.

name: Aaliyah Johnson
clarity_response: A curated events recommendation tool that filters NYC activities to a shortlist based on your preferences.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
weakest_section: Objection handling is too long. By the time I get to the fifth objection I've lost interest. Nobody reads five Q&As.
what_feels_off: The tone is a bit too clever in places. 'No engagement farming' — okay, but that's what everyone says.
objections: Waitlist with no timeline. I've signed up for waitlists that never launched. Show me a beta or something concrete.
gut_reaction: Solid positioning. Clearly built by someone who understands the problem. But the execution is TBD and the waitlist doesn't inspire confidence.
unanswered_questions: How do you source events? Is it human-curated or algorithmic? What's the actual business model?
share_trigger: I'd share it if I could say 'look, this actually works' — not 'hey, join a waitlist with me.'

name: Mei-Lin Wu
clarity_response: A personalized shortlist app for NYC events and activities. Gives you 3-5 picks instead of overwhelming you.
strongest_line: Your weekend shouldn't take longer to plan than to enjoy.
weakest_section: The example card. Kehinde Wiley is great but it feels like it's trying to prove cultural credibility. Would have been more convincing with a mix of highbrow and casual.
what_feels_off: The whole page assumes I'm a 24-year-old who goes to gallery openings. I'm 30 and sometimes I just want a good trivia night.
objections: Seems art/culture skewed. I want to see variety — sports bars, trivia, casual hangouts. Not just gallery shows.
gut_reaction: I get it and the problem is real. But the example makes me wonder if this is actually for me or for a very specific type of NYC person.
unanswered_questions: Is this only for 'cultured' activities? Does it cover casual stuff like bowling, karaoke, bar trivia?
share_trigger: If the categories actually included casual/lowkey stuff, I'd send it to my friend group. We're not gallery people.

name: Omar Farouk
clarity_response: An app that asks what you're into and gives you a small list of NYC things to do that match. Filters by time, distance, budget.
strongest_line: Tell us what you're into, when you're free, and how far you'll go. We'll tell you what's worth your time.
weakest_section: The CTA section repeats what the hero already said. By the end I feel like I've read the same pitch three times.
what_feels_off: Slightly repetitive. The value prop is clear by Section 2 but the page keeps restating it.
objections: Waitlist — I want to use it now. Also, I just moved here. Will it help me explore neighborhoods I don't know yet?
gut_reaction: Finally someone gets it. I literally spend my Thursday evenings researching weekends and end up doing nothing new.
unanswered_questions: Can it help me explore neighborhoods I haven't been to? Does the distance filter account for subway time or just distance?
share_trigger: I'd share it with my work friends immediately — we all have this exact problem.

name: Tamika Harris
clarity_response: A curated activity finder for NYC that narrows events down to a few personalized picks based on your interests and schedule.
strongest_line: Stop scrolling six apps just to figure out what to do this weekend.
weakest_section: Social proof quotes are from people in their 20s. Are there older users? Feels narrow.
what_feels_off: I'm in social media — I know how this game works. The quotes feel curated for maximum relatability, which ironically makes them feel less authentic.
objections: I've seen a lot of apps promise this. How is this different from the 3 other 'curated NYC events' apps that launched and died? Where's the data coming from?
gut_reaction: Good copy. Problem is real. But I've been burned by similar pitches. Need to see the actual product.
unanswered_questions: How large is the event database? Who's curating? Is there a team or is it just an algorithm scraping Eventbrite?
share_trigger: If someone I trust was already using it and said it was good. Waitlist pages don't get shared.

name: Keiko Yamamoto
clarity_response: An app that gives you a handful of NYC activity recommendations instead of making you sort through everything yourself.
strongest_line: Not a feed. Not 200 results. A shortlist.
weakest_section: Objection handling about 'already apps for this' — the dismissal of Eventbrite/Fever feels a bit cocky for a product that doesn't exist yet.
what_feels_off: Calling out competitors by name before you've launched feels risky. Prove yourself first.
objections: The competitive positioning is aggressive for a waitlist-stage product. Show me the product working, then tell me why Eventbrite sucks.
gut_reaction: I'd use this. The problem description is spot on. But punching at Eventbrite when you're pre-launch is a vibe mismatch.
unanswered_questions: What does the actual UI look like? Is there a demo or screenshots?
share_trigger: The concept is great for sharing — 'stop scrolling six apps' is a meme-worthy line. But not until I can show actual results.

name: Liam O'Brien
clarity_response: A NYC events recommendation service that gives you a filtered shortlist based on your interests, availability, and location.
strongest_line: We spend most of our time looking into activities that we end up not even going anymore.
weakest_section: The 'how do you know what I'll like' objection response. 'Recommendations get sharper the more you use it' is vague. How?
what_feels_off: The 'gets sharper over time' claim is hand-wavy. Every app says this. What's the mechanism?
objections: No clarity on how personalization works. I don't want to invest time teaching an algorithm that might not learn.
gut_reaction: The Sam quote in social proof is basically my life. The problem articulation is strong. The solution description needs more specifics.
unanswered_questions: How does personalization actually work? Is it AI? Collaborative filtering? Human editors?
share_trigger: The Sam quote alone is shareable. 'We spend most of our time looking and end up not going' — I'd screenshot that.

name: Jenna Liu
clarity_response: A curated events app for NYC that filters activities to a shortlist.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
weakest_section: CTA. 'Join the waitlist' is the weakest possible ask. I need more specificity about when this launches and what I'll get.
what_feels_off: The energy is high but the ask is low. 'Join a waitlist' after a page this confident feels anticlimactic.
objections: My friends are in different neighborhoods now. The real problem is coordination, not discovery. This doesn't solve group planning at all.
gut_reaction: Well-written but misses my actual pain point. I can find things — the issue is getting 5 people in 3 boroughs to agree on one.
unanswered_questions: Any group planning features? Can friends see the same shortlist? Is there shared decision-making?
share_trigger: If it had a 'share shortlist with friends' feature, I'd immediately try it with my group.

name: Ethan Nakamura
clarity_response: A personalized weekly shortlist of things to do in NYC based on what you like and when you're free.
strongest_line: A Thursday shortlist for your weekend.
weakest_section: Social proof — all the quotes are from women in their 20s. Feels like it's only for one demographic.
what_feels_off: The demographic feel is narrow. All 20-something women. Are men using this? Older people? Couples?
objections: Is this just for young women? The social proof makes it feel that way. Also, no solo-activity focus — I'm looking for things to do alone sometimes.
gut_reaction: The Thursday shortlist idea is genuinely smart. But I need to feel like this is for people like me, not just a very specific lifestyle blogger type.
unanswered_questions: Is this good for solo activities? Does it work for couples? Is the user base diverse?
share_trigger: If I could share a personalized shortlist with a 'here's what I'm doing this weekend' message, that's a natural share moment.

name: Lucia Ferraro
clarity_response: An app that recommends 3-5 things to do in NYC each weekend based on your preferences and constraints.
strongest_line: Stop scrolling six apps just to figure out what to do this weekend.
weakest_section: How It Works section is too text-heavy. I want to see screenshots or a gif of the actual flow, not read about it.
what_feels_off: All copy, no visuals. I'm reading a lot of words about how simple this is, which is ironic.
objections: Show me. Don't tell me. The page describes simplicity with a lot of words. A screenshot would do more than three paragraphs.
gut_reaction: I'm sold on the concept. Headline grabbed me. But the page itself is too wordy for something selling simplicity.
unanswered_questions: What does it actually look like? Any screenshots? A demo?
share_trigger: The headline alone. I'd text that to my group chat: 'stop scrolling six apps' — that's our whole group.

name: Theo Papadopoulos
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity finder that narrows options to 3-5 personalized picks based on interests, schedule, budget, and location.
strongest_line: You don't need more options. You need the right 3–5, matched to what you actually care about — before they're gone.
weakest_section: The quick-qualify question at the end feels like an afterthought. If the product is about personalization, shouldn't this be more prominent?
what_feels_off: Minor thing — 'before they're gone' in the subheadline feels slightly fear-mongery. I get it, but it triggers my 'manipulation radar' slightly.
objections: Waitlist with no date. Also, how complete is the event database? If I try it and my niche categories have 2 events, I'm gone.
gut_reaction: This reads like someone transcribed my Thursday evening anxiety. Very strong problem articulation. I'm cautiously in.
unanswered_questions: Launch timeline? Event coverage breadth? Does it cover Brooklyn neighborhood-level events or just Manhattan-centric stuff?
share_trigger: I'd share the concept with my content friends — we all talk about this exact problem. The copy itself would make a good case study.

name: Danielle Brooks
clarity_response: A personalized recommendations app for NYC events that gives you a filtered shortlist instead of an overwhelming feed.
strongest_line: 6 out of 10 said they've given up on plans because the search took too long.
weakest_section: The notification objection feels defensive. I didn't even think about notifications until you brought it up. Now I'm thinking about it.
what_feels_off: The notification objection raises a concern I didn't have. Classic over-objection-handling — sometimes you plant the seed of doubt by trying to preempt it.
objections: Slight 'are they overthinking this?' energy. The product seems simple but the page is pretty long for a waitlist.
gut_reaction: Good problem. Good concept. Page is about 30% too long. Could lose two objection blocks and be stronger.
unanswered_questions: Business model? Is this VC-backed? Will it stay curated or become another ad-filled feed?
share_trigger: If I could sign up and get results within a week, I'd share. A waitlist is a harder sell to forward.

name: Elena Petrov
clarity_response: An app that recommends things to do in NYC based on what you like. Gives you a shortlist instead of a big list.
strongest_line: Pick from categories like live music, art exhibitions, pop-ups, outdoor activities.
weakest_section: Hero section. 'Stop scrolling six apps' — I don't scroll six apps. I just ask my friends. This doesn't speak to me.
what_feels_off: The pain point assumes I'm a heavy searcher. I'm not. I'm a heavy defaulter. Different problem.
objections: I don't search six apps — I just go where my friends go. This seems built for planners, not for people stuck in routines.
gut_reaction: I see the appeal but it's not describing my problem. I don't have analysis paralysis — I have habit paralysis.
unanswered_questions: Does this push me to try new things or just make the search faster? I need the former, not the latter.
share_trigger: If it showed me something I'd never heard of that looked actually cool, I'd share that specific event. Not the app page.

name: Amira Khalil
clarity_response: A personalized event recommendation tool for NYC. Filters events by your interests and schedule.
strongest_line: Or go broad and let us surprise you.
weakest_section: The entire framing assumes my problem is too many options. My problem is too little motivation. Those are different.
what_feels_off: This is solving a search problem. I have a motivation problem. Giving me a better list won't make me leave my couch.
objections: I'm skeptical an app changes behavior. I know what's out there — I just default to easy. Will this push me, or just organize what I already ignore?
gut_reaction: Well-written page but it's not for me. I don't struggle to find things. I struggle to do them.
unanswered_questions: Does it have any accountability features? Reminders? Social nudges? Just giving me a list isn't enough.
share_trigger: If it sent me a compelling, specific push on Thursday that made me go 'oh, that's this weekend?' — that moment is shareable.

name: Darius Jackson
clarity_response: A curated list of NYC things to do, narrowed to 3-5 options based on what you care about.
strongest_line: Your weekend shouldn't take longer to plan than to enjoy.
weakest_section: No mention of couple-friendly or date activities. It feels very individual or friend-group focused.
what_feels_off: The social proof is all single-sounding 20-somethings. Where are the couples? The 30+?
objections: My partner and I need date ideas beyond dinner. Does this surface romantic or couple-friendly activities? The page doesn't mention it.
gut_reaction: The problem is real for us. But the page speaks to a single young professional, not a couple looking for something different together.
unanswered_questions: Can you filter for date-appropriate activities? Is there a 'couples' or 'date night' category?
share_trigger: If I could send my partner a shortlist of date ideas for this weekend with a 'pick one' — that's instantly shareable.

name: Natasha Ivanova
clarity_response: An NYC activity discovery app that personalizes a shortlist of 3-5 things to do based on your interests and constraints.
strongest_line: We filter so you don't have to.
weakest_section: Example card is art-focused. I was hoping to see a fitness or outdoor example too. One art card makes me think this is a gallery app.
what_feels_off: The example card creates an impression that might not match me. I'm into fitness events, run clubs, outdoor stuff. The art gallery example almost lost me.
objections: Is this mostly art and culture? I want run clubs, outdoor yoga, fitness pop-ups. The example card worried me.
gut_reaction: Good until the example card, which made me pause. Then I re-read the categories and fitness is listed, so okay. But first impressions matter.
unanswered_questions: How strong is the fitness/outdoor category? Is that equally curated or an afterthought?
share_trigger: If it surfaced a cool fitness event I didn't know about in my new neighborhood, I'd screenshot that and send it to my fitness friends.

name: Marcus Thompson
clarity_response: A shortlist generator for NYC events. You set preferences and it gives you a few curated picks.
strongest_line: Let us surprise you.
weakest_section: Everything below 'How It Works.' The page gets long and I stopped reading.
what_feels_off: The page is too long for a waitlist. I got the point in 10 seconds but then had to scroll through 5 more sections.
objections: I'm not signing up for a waitlist for something I'll forget about. Send me a text when it's live.
gut_reaction: Cool idea, too many words. I skimmed after the hero. If this is about simplicity, the page should be simpler.
unanswered_questions: When does it launch? Why so much copy for a waitlist?
share_trigger: Nothing on this page specifically. But if the 'surprise me' feature actually worked, I'd tell everyone.

name: Morgan Reilly
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity recommendation tool that gives you 3-5 filtered picks for your weekend.
strongest_line: Not a feed. Not 200 results. A shortlist.
weakest_section: Social proof stats. N=50 is too small to cite percentages from. '87% of people we interviewed' — that's like 43 people. Don't cite that as a stat.
what_feels_off: As a designer, the stats from 50 interviews presented as percentages feels statistically dishonest. It undermines trust.
objections: The n=50 stats bother me. Also, no mention of how this handles friend groups or solo use.
gut_reaction: Strong UX thinking. The 3-filter flow is well designed conceptually. But the social proof section needs work — real designers will see through thin stats.
unanswered_questions: Solo vs group use? How does the recommendation engine actually work?
share_trigger: If I could try the 3-step flow and it actually returned good results, that experience would be highly shareable.

name: Yusuf Abdi
clarity_response: A curated events app that shortlists NYC activities matching your interests, time, and budget.
strongest_line: Tell us what you're into, when you're free, and how far you'll go.
weakest_section: The objection about 'already apps for this' — it reads slightly defensive. If the product is good, you shouldn't need to compare yourself.
what_feels_off: Minor — the competitive comparison feels like insecurity, not confidence. Let the product speak.
objections: I'm rebuilding my social habits. Does this help me find things to do alone, or is it all group-oriented?
gut_reaction: I like the approach. The problem resonates — especially the 'give up and stay home' thing. But I'm in a solo phase and this feels group-oriented.
unanswered_questions: Solo-friendly activities? Can I say 'just me, Saturday afternoon, walking distance'?
share_trigger: If it understood solo activities and could recommend 'things to do alone this weekend,' I'd share that use case.

name: Gabrielle Moreau
clarity_response: A filtered NYC events list based on your preferences. 3-5 recommendations instead of overwhelming options.
strongest_line: The events you miss because they never show up in your Instagram feed until the last day? We track those.
weakest_section: The whole thing assumes I have standard weekend free time. I work nights. My 'weekend' is Tuesday-Wednesday. Nothing here addresses non-standard schedules.
what_feels_off: Very weekend-centric language. 'Your weekend,' 'Thursday shortlist for your weekend.' My schedule doesn't work that way.
objections: Does this only work for 9-to-5 schedules? I need Tuesday afternoon things, not Saturday night things. The copy makes me feel excluded.
gut_reaction: The tracking niche events angle is interesting. But the weekend-centric framing signals this isn't built for people with nonstandard schedules.
unanswered_questions: Can I set non-standard free times? Does it track weekday events equally?
share_trigger: If it surfaced a secret Tuesday jazz set I'd never find otherwise, that's worth sharing.

name: Fatima Al-Hassan
clarity_response: An app that recommends 3-5 curated NYC activities based on what you like, when you're free, and how far you'll go.
strongest_line: How far will you travel?
weakest_section: No mention of neighborhood discovery. I know Cobble Hill inside out — I need to be pushed to other neighborhoods.
what_feels_off: The distance filter is mentioned but not framed as 'expand your world.' It's framed as 'how far will you go' which implies staying close.
objections: I want to be nudged to explore beyond my neighborhood. Will this just show me things within 10 minutes or will it push me further?
gut_reaction: Like the simplicity promise. But I need a 'push me out of my bubble' option, not just a distance limiter.
unanswered_questions: Is there a 'surprise me with a new neighborhood' feature?
share_trigger: If it showed me an incredible thing in a neighborhood I've never been to, I'd share that discovery.

name: Aisha Rahman
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity app that gives you 3-5 personalized recommendations instead of endless browsing.
strongest_line: Stop scrolling six apps just to figure out what to do this weekend.
weakest_section: The 'gets sharper the more you use it' claim. Every app says this. Most don't deliver.
what_feels_off: Slightly over-promises on personalization for an app that doesn't exist yet. How sharp can it be at launch?
objections: Will it be good from day one or do I need to 'train' it for weeks? Cold start problem.
gut_reaction: I'd try it. The brunch-bar-repeat cycle is real and embarrassing. If this breaks it even once, it's worth it.
unanswered_questions: How good is it from day one? What's the cold-start experience like?
share_trigger: If it broke my brunch-bar cycle with one good recommendation, I'd evangelize it.

name: Jake Rosenberg
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity shortlist that filters down to 3-5 curated recommendations based on your preferences.
strongest_line: You don't need more options. You need the right 3–5.
weakest_section: No 'at home' alternatives. Sometimes I want to know if anything is worth leaving the apartment for. If nothing is, say so.
what_feels_off: Assumes I always want to go out. Sometimes the answer is 'stay home, there's nothing great tonight.' That honesty would build trust.
objections: Will it ever say 'nothing great this weekend, stay in'? Or will it always push 5 things? Overpromising kills trust.
gut_reaction: This is the app my partner and I need. We default to Netflix because deciding what to do is harder than doing nothing.
unanswered_questions: Will it be honest when there's nothing great? Can two people use it together?
share_trigger: I'd share this with my partner immediately. 'Look, this might finally get us off the couch.'

name: Renée Dubois
clarity_response: An events recommendation app for NYC that gives you a shortlist instead of a full list.
strongest_line: What's your budget — free only, under $20, or no limit?
weakest_section: The page is very Manhattan-energy. Sunset Park, Bay Ridge, these neighborhoods never show up in NYC apps. Will mine?
what_feels_off: The example card is in Chelsea. The quotes are from Midtown East, UES, Brooklyn (but vague Brooklyn). Outer boroughs feel invisible.
objections: Will this cover my neighborhood or is it another Manhattan-first app? If I set my distance to 20 minutes, will I just get nothing?
dealbreaker_reason: If this doesn't cover events in outer Brooklyn and Queens, it's useless to me. And there's no indication it will.
gut_reaction: Cool for people in Manhattan and trendy Brooklyn. Not sure it's for me in Sunset Park.
unanswered_questions: What neighborhoods are covered? Is this Manhattan-centric?
share_trigger: If it showed me something cool in Sunset Park I didn't know about, I'd share that. But I doubt it will.

name: Andre Williams
clarity_response: A filtered NYC event recommendation tool that narrows activities to a short personalized list based on preferences and constraints.
strongest_line: No social media profile required. No influencer algorithm. Just your preferences.
weakest_section: Social proof. The stats from 50 interviews are not statistically meaningful. I would never cite percentages from n=50.
what_feels_off: The sample size for the stats is too small. '87% of people we interviewed' — that's maybe 44 people agreeing. That's not a stat, that's an anecdote.
objections: Show me how the algorithm works. 'Gets sharper over time' is a black box claim. I need transparency or I don't trust it.
gut_reaction: The 'no influencer algorithm' line earned my attention. But the vague personalization claims immediately spent that goodwill.
unanswered_questions: How does the algorithm work? What data does it use? Can I see why something was recommended?
share_trigger: If it showed me the reasoning behind each recommendation transparently, that would be noteworthy enough to share.

name: Kira Johansson
clarity_response: A curated events shortlist for NYC. Sets preferences, gets 3-5 filtered picks.
strongest_line: A shortlist — with the details you need to just go: what it is, where, when, how much, and why it matched you.
weakest_section: The urgency language. 'Before they're gone,' 'ends in 17 days.' I don't respond to manufactured urgency.
what_feels_off: FOMO-based language. 'Before they're gone' is a classic urgency tactic. If the product is good, you don't need to scare me into it.
objections: The urgency framing feels manipulative. I'm the kind of person who will walk away from anything that pressures me.
gut_reaction: I like the filtering concept. I dislike the urgency marketing. Mixed feelings.
unanswered_questions: Can I use this at my own pace without time-pressure notifications?
share_trigger: If it consistently surfaced quiet, quality things — a great bookshop event, a small gallery talk — I'd tell specific friends.

name: Adrienne Cole
clarity_response: An NYC activity recommendation service that gives a curated shortlist of 3-5 personalized events based on interests, timing, location, and budget.
strongest_line: Why it matched you.
weakest_section: The objection about 'how do you know what I'll like' — the answer is too casual. 'Just pick a few categories' undersells what should be a sophisticated matching system.
what_feels_off: The casualness of 'just pick a few categories' doesn't match the sophistication the product promises. Either the matching is smart or it's basic — can't be both.
objections: The gap between 'simple onboarding' and 'accurate recommendations' isn't bridged. How do 3 category picks lead to genuinely good matches?
gut_reaction: The 'why it matched you' element is exactly what I want. If executed well, this would replace my manual Google Maps research.
unanswered_questions: What's the matching sophistication? Is it rules-based or learned? How quickly does it improve?
share_trigger: If the 'why it matched you' feature was genuinely insightful, I'd show it to my partner as evidence we should try something.

name: Olivia Santos
clarity_response: A filtered event recommendation system for NYC. Shortlists instead of full search.
strongest_line: No engagement farming.
weakest_section: Everything feels oriented toward extroverts. Live music, pop-ups, food events — where are the quiet activities?
what_feels_off: The categories are all social. Where's 'quiet afternoon activity,' 'solo museum visit,' 'bookshop event'? I feel like I'm not the target user.
objections: This seems built for people who go out a lot. I go out once a week max. The categories don't include what I typically do.
dealbreaker_reason: If the categories don't include quiet, solo, or low-key activities, this isn't for me.
gut_reaction: Interesting concept but the vibe is too extroverted for me. Every example is a social activity.
unanswered_questions: Does this cater to introverts? Are there solo/quiet categories?
share_trigger: If it genuinely understood introvert preferences — a small poetry reading, a quiet garden — I'd be a dedicated user and tell friends like me.

name: Tara Patel
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity shortlist app. Filters events to 3-5 based on what you like and when you're free.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
weakest_section: No mention of privacy. Will my preferences be used for ads? Will other people see what I'm interested in? This matters to me.
what_feels_off: No privacy mention anywhere. In 2026, any app that collects preferences needs to address data privacy upfront.
objections: What do you do with my data? Is this profile public? Can friends see what I'm browsing? Privacy is non-negotiable for me.
gut_reaction: Solid concept, missing a privacy story. I keep private lists for a reason — I don't want my taste data monetized or shared.
unanswered_questions: Privacy policy? Data usage? Social visibility controls? Can I keep my preferences private?
share_trigger: If I could share a specific event without sharing my entire profile or history, that would be the right level of sharing.

name: Raj Patel
clarity_response: A curated NYC events app. Narrows options to a shortlist based on preferences.
strongest_line: The #1 pain point across every interview: 'too many options, not enough good ones.'
weakest_section: The entire promise hinges on curation quality, but there's zero evidence the curation is good. No examples of actual past recommendations. The one example card is hypothetical.
what_feels_off: I'm being asked to trust a curation engine that has no track record. The page sells the concept but not the competence.
objections: How do I know your taste is good? Every platform claims curation. Most are just popularity-ranked. What's different here?
dealbreaker_reason: No evidence of curation quality. I won't sign up based on promises alone.
gut_reaction: The problem exists. The solution might work. But this page gives me zero evidence it'll actually be good. It's a pitch, not proof.
unanswered_questions: What's the curation methodology? Who decides what's 'worth doing'? Is it human or algorithmic?
share_trigger: If I used it for a month and the recommendations were consistently excellent, I'd tell my trusted circle. Not before.

name: Simone Baptiste
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity recommendation tool that gives you a curated shortlist of 3-5 things based on your interests, schedule, location, and budget.
strongest_line: What it is, where, when, how much, and why it matched you.
weakest_section: The page doesn't address seasonality. NYC activities change dramatically by season. Will it be good in winter? Summer?
what_feels_off: The copy is strong but season-agnostic. Right now it's February — what's it recommending in the dead of winter?
objections: Seasonal coverage gap. Also, 'gets sharper over time' — how long before it's actually good?
gut_reaction: I appreciate the specificity of the match criteria ('why it matched you'). That's what I look for when making decisions.
unanswered_questions: Seasonal coverage? Winter-specific recommendations? How long until personalization kicks in?
share_trigger: If the 'why it matched you' reasoning was genuinely thoughtful and not just keyword matching, I'd recommend it to analytical friends.

name: Jamal Carter
clarity_response: An app that narrows down NYC events and activities to a shortlist of 3-5 options matched to your preferences.
strongest_line: Zero rabbit holes.
weakest_section: Social proof. These are clearly cherry-picked interview quotes. Show me actual user results, not pre-launch interview snippets.
what_feels_off: The social proof is from your own research interviews, not from actual product users. That's not social proof — that's market research presented as validation.
objections: You're citing your own interviews as social proof. That's not the same as actual users vouching for a product that works.
gut_reaction: Honest about what it is. But I won't believe the curation is good until I see it work.
unanswered_questions: When can I try it? Are there actual users already? What does a real shortlist look like?
share_trigger: Zero share triggers on this page. Share triggers come from product experience, not landing pages.

name: Diana Tran
clarity_response: A curated shortlist of NYC activities — 3-5 picks personalized to your interests, time, and location.
strongest_line: You're right — it is. That's why we don't just list every free event. We filter for quality.
weakest_section: The example card. Kehinde Wiley is a well-known artist — showing me something everyone already knows about doesn't prove you find hidden things.
what_feels_off: The example is too mainstream. If you're claiming to surface niche stuff, the example should be something I've genuinely never heard of.
objections: The Kehinde Wiley example undermines the 'niche discovery' promise. It should be something actually obscure.
gut_reaction: The free events objection response was honest and earned my trust. The example card slightly lost it.
unanswered_questions: What's an example of something genuinely niche you'd surface? The current example is mainstream art.
share_trigger: If it recommended something truly hidden and great that I attended, I'd quietly tell the 2-3 friends who'd appreciate it.

name: Nina Aleksandrov
clarity_response: An NYC events shortlist tool. Filters activities based on interests and constraints to give you 3-5 options.
strongest_line: No influencer algorithm.
weakest_section: How It Works is oversimplified. 'Pick categories, set filters, get shortlist.' That's what every app says. What's the actual intelligence behind it?
what_feels_off: The simplicity sell feels like it's hiding a lack of sophistication. Simple UX is great. Simple algorithm is not.
objections: I need to understand the recommendation logic. 'Pick categories and set filters' is just search with fewer results. That's not curation.
dealbreaker_reason: If the 'curation' is just filtered search (category + location + date), that's not better than what I already do myself.
gut_reaction: Skeptical. The page promises curation but describes search. Those are fundamentally different things.
unanswered_questions: Is this actually curated or just filtered? What makes the recommendations intelligent beyond basic matching?
share_trigger: Only if the recommendations were consistently surprising and excellent. Not based on a landing page.

name: Ben Shapiro-Stein
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity discovery tool that gives a curated shortlist of 3-5 events based on your preferences.
strongest_line: Exhibitions ending this week, sample sales, limited-run shows, neighborhood pop-ups.
weakest_section: Very weekend-focused. I'm free Tuesday-Thursday. The language is all 'your weekend' and 'Saturday.' What about weekday events?
what_feels_off: Weekday events exist and are often better (fewer crowds, more intimate). The weekend-only framing misses a whole audience.
objections: Does this work for weekday activities or is it a weekend-only tool?
gut_reaction: The 'endings this week' angle is smart and relevant to my professional life. But the weekend framing gives me pause.
unanswered_questions: Weekday coverage? Can I set my free days to Tuesday-Thursday?
share_trigger: If it alerted me to exhibitions ending soon that I hadn't caught in my professional channels, that'd be worth telling colleagues about.

name: Sade Adeyemi
clarity_response: An AI-powered personalized shortlist of NYC activities. 3-5 curated options based on interests, timing, and budget.
strongest_line: Why it matched you.
weakest_section: No mention of how the algorithm handles diversity of recommendations. Will it pigeonhole me or actively expand my horizons?
what_feels_off: Missing the expansion angle. If I always pick 'jazz' will it only show me jazz? Or will it occasionally say 'you might also like this poetry reading'?
objections: Filter bubbles are real. Will this trap me in my own preferences or help me discover things outside my comfort zone?
gut_reaction: Promising approach. The transparency element ('why it matched') is what most recommendation systems lack. I'm cautiously interested.
unanswered_questions: Recommendation diversity? Filter bubble prevention? Does it expand taste or just mirror it?
share_trigger: If it recommended something genuinely outside my usual interests that I ended up loving, that'd be a compelling story to share.

name: Rachel Park
clarity_response: A personalized discovery tool for NYC events — exhibitions, pop-ups, cultural programming — that gives you a curated shortlist based on your interests and timing.
strongest_line: The events you miss because they never show up in your Instagram feed until the last day? We track those.
weakest_section: The example card is good but I want to see 3-5 cards, not one. Show me the actual shortlist experience.
what_feels_off: Only one example card. If the product is '3-5 picks,' show me 3-5 picks. One card doesn't prove the concept.
objections: I need to see the catalog. If I sign up and there are 20 events total, this is useless. Coverage is everything for this product.
gut_reaction: This is exactly what I've been looking for. The niche tracking angle is the killer feature. But catalog depth will make or break it.
unanswered_questions: How many events are tracked? What sources? Do you have partnerships with galleries and venues?
share_trigger: I'd share this with my culture-interested friends today. The concept alone is worth discussing.

name: Tomás Guerrero
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity shortlist app focused on filtering events to 3-5 personalized recommendations.
strongest_line: Exhibitions ending this week, sample sales, limited-run shows, neighborhood pop-ups.
weakest_section: I work in a gallery. The Kehinde Wiley example is mainstream. If you showed me something I didn't already know about, that'd be impressive. This doesn't.
what_feels_off: For someone in the art world, the example card reads as basic. It's like recommending MoMA to a museum curator.
objections: Will this surface things that even insiders miss? Or is it just aggregating what's already well-known? The example suggests the latter.
gut_reaction: The promise is right. The proof isn't there yet. If the catalog goes deep enough to surprise me, I'm a power user. If not, I'm gone in a week.
unanswered_questions: How deep does the catalog go? Small galleries? Artist studios? Project spaces? Or just the big names?
share_trigger: If it surfaced an exhibition at a space I didn't know existed, I'd share that with every art friend I have.

name: Zara Osei
clarity_response: A personalized NYC events shortlist — cultural activities, exhibitions, pop-ups — filtered and timed so you don't miss them.
strongest_line: Before they're gone.
weakest_section: Social proof doesn't include anyone who sounds like me — a cultural professional in his 30s. The quotes are all 20-somethings.
what_feels_off: The demographic of the social proof is narrow. I'm 34. The quotes make this feel like a product for recent grads.
objections: Is this for young professionals only? The social proof and vibe skew young. I need to know it's sophisticated enough for someone with developed taste.
gut_reaction: The timing problem is perfectly articulated. Finding out about things after they end is my actual life. If this solves that, I'm committed.
unanswered_questions: Target demographic? Will recommendations be sophisticated enough for cultural professionals?
share_trigger: The 'before they're gone' concept is immediately shareable. I'd send the page to colleagues who miss things constantly.

name: Esme Blackwell
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist tool that curates 3-5 personalized picks from cultural events, pop-ups, and activities.
strongest_line: If it has a date and it's worth knowing about, it should be here.
weakest_section: Fashion events are mentioned nowhere specifically. 'Pop-ups & sample sales' is close but not the same as fashion events, trunk shows, designer releases.
what_feels_off: The category list in Step 1 doesn't include fashion. That's a big omission for a NYC lifestyle product.
objections: Fashion events are a huge part of NYC culture and they're not mentioned. If this is supposed to be comprehensive, where's fashion?
gut_reaction: Good concept. Missing fashion as a category is a blind spot. Sample sales are not the same as fashion events.
unanswered_questions: Does it cover fashion specifically? Trunk shows, presentations, showroom events? Or just general 'pop-ups'?
share_trigger: If it tracked fashion events and insider sales that aren't on Instagram yet, I'd share it with my entire industry network.

name: Nikolai Volkov
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity recommendation tool that gives you 3-5 filtered options based on your preferences, schedule, and location.
strongest_line: Matched because: you liked immersive art + you're free Saturday + it's 12 min from you.
weakest_section: Objection about 'already apps for this' — slightly dismissive of Fever. I've had good Fever experiences. Don't trash the competition.
what_feels_off: The Eventbrite/Fever dismissal feels cocky. I've used Fever and liked some things. Acknowledging competitors' strengths while showing your advantage would be more honest.
objections: The competitive positioning is slightly arrogant. Also, 'sample sales' are listed but I care more about design and architecture events.
gut_reaction: The match reasoning is the strongest element. 'Why it matched you' makes this feel genuinely personalized, not just filtered.
unanswered_questions: Does it cover design and architecture events? Pop-up showrooms? Studio visits?
share_trigger: If the match reasoning was consistently smart and I could share individual event cards, I'd send those to design friends.

name: Courtney Ng
clarity_response: A personalized shortlist of NYC events. Filters down to 3-5 curated recommendations based on interests and timing.
strongest_line: Zero rabbit holes.
weakest_section: The product description focuses on filtering DOWN. But I want it to also expand me — show me things I wouldn't have searched for.
what_feels_off: Very filter-centric. Filtering implies narrowing what you already know you want. Discovery implies showing you what you didn't know you wanted. This page sells filtering, not discovery.
objections: Where's the serendipity? I want to be surprised. 'Pick your categories and we'll match' isn't surprising — it's organized searching.
gut_reaction: Strong execution on the 'reduce overwhelm' pitch. Weaker on the 'expand your world' pitch. I want both.
unanswered_questions: Will it proactively suggest things outside my stated preferences? Does it optimize for comfort or growth?
share_trigger: If it introduced me to a completely new type of event I ended up loving, that story would spread organically in my network.

name: Sofia Reyes
clarity_response: A curated NYC events app. Pick interests, set filters, get a shortlist of 3-5 things to do.
strongest_line: Or go broad and let us surprise you.
weakest_section: No community angle. I don't just want to attend things — I want to find my people. Craft events, maker spaces, creative community.
what_feels_off: Very consumption-oriented. 'Go to this event, go to that event.' Missing the community/belonging angle entirely.
objections: I want to find recurring events where I see the same faces. A one-off shortlist doesn't build community.
gut_reaction: Useful but incomplete. Discovery is step one. Community is the real goal.
unanswered_questions: Does it track recurring events? Can I find ongoing communities, not just one-off events?
share_trigger: If it connected me with a maker community I didn't know existed, I'd talk about it constantly.

name: Samuel Obi
clarity_response: An NYC activity recommendation platform that shortlists 3-5 personalized picks from events, exhibitions, and pop-ups.
strongest_line: Built from conversations with 50+ New Yorkers who were tired of the same weekend.
weakest_section: The 'How do you know what I'll like' objection. The answer is 'you tell us' — but what if I don't know what I want? The whole point is discovery.
what_feels_off: Tension between 'tell us what you want' and 'we'll show you new things.' If I already knew what I wanted, I wouldn't need this.
objections: The onboarding flow assumes I know my preferences. The most interesting discoveries come from NOT knowing what you want.
gut_reaction: Professionally crafted page. The problem articulation is sharp. The solution needs a stronger 'surprise me' narrative alongside the filter narrative.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle 'I don't know what I want'? Is there a pure serendipity mode?
share_trigger: If the surprise mode consistently delivered interesting, unexpected events, that would be very word-of-mouth worthy.

name: Priya Nair
clarity_response: A centralized discovery tool for NYC cultural events and activities. Personalized shortlist of 3-5 curated picks.
strongest_line: The events you miss because they never show up in your Instagram feed until the last day? We track those.
weakest_section: The quick-qualify question at the end feels basic. 'Art exhibitions & galleries' is one option? That's like 15 categories smushed into one.
what_feels_off: The category granularity in the quick-qualify is too coarse. 'Art exhibitions' and 'gallery openings' are very different things.
objections: Category granularity. If you group all of art into one bucket, you'll recommend MoMA to someone who only wants project spaces. That's a trust-killer.
gut_reaction: I follow 30+ accounts and still miss things. If this consolidates what I'm already trying to track manually, it's genuinely valuable.
unanswered_questions: How granular are the categories? Can I distinguish between museums, galleries, project spaces, and studio visits?
share_trigger: I'd share this immediately. My art world friends all have this exact problem.

name: Ravi Krishnan
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity shortlist — cultural events, pop-ups, exhibitions — filtered to 3-5 options based on your preferences.
strongest_line: Limited-run shows, neighborhood pop-ups. If it has a date and it's worth knowing about, it should be here.
weakest_section: Theater isn't mentioned in the categories. Live music is there but not theater, performance art, or dance. Major omission for NYC.
what_feels_off: How do you have a NYC cultural events app without theater as a category? That's like having a food app without restaurants.
objections: Missing theater/performance art category. If this is supposed to be comprehensive for NYC culture, that's a gap.
gut_reaction: The concept is needed. The category list needs work. Theater, dance, and performance art should be front and center.
unanswered_questions: Does it cover theater? Off-off-Broadway? Performance art? Dance?
share_trigger: If it tracked small theater companies and off-off-Broadway, I'd share it with every theater person I know.

name: Paloma Cruz
clarity_response: An NYC events curation tool. Shortlists 3-5 personalized activities based on interests, timing, and budget.
strongest_line: Matched because: you liked immersive art + you're free Saturday + it's 12 min from you.
weakest_section: The 'How do you know what I'll like' answer. I recently got into ceramics. Will this surface ceramics classes and studios even though I've never rated one?
what_feels_off: 'Recommendations get sharper the more you use it' — but I need it to be good on week one for my new interest, not after months of training.
objections: Cold start for new interests. I just got into ceramics. How does it know that if I haven't rated anything in that category?
gut_reaction: Good concept. But if I have to spend weeks teaching it before it understands my evolving interests, that's too much friction.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle new or evolving interests? Can I add new categories mid-use?
share_trigger: If it found me a ceramics studio visit I couldn't have found on my own, that's a conversion moment.

name: Yara Nazari
clarity_response: A personalized NYC cultural events shortlist tool. 3-5 filtered recommendations based on interests and schedule.
strongest_line: Not a feed. Not 200 results. A shortlist.
weakest_section: No mention of editorial perspective or taste. Who's curating? An algorithm? Editors? The city's best cultural critics? Curation quality depends on who's behind it.
what_feels_off: Anonymous curation. I want to know there's a human with taste behind this, not just an event scraper with filters.
objections: Who's curating? If it's just algorithmic matching, that's Google with a prettier interface. I want editorial judgment.
gut_reaction: The shortlist concept is right. The question is whether the taste behind the recommendations is good enough to earn my trust.
unanswered_questions: Who's behind the curation? Is there an editorial voice or just an algorithm?
share_trigger: If the editorial taste was consistently excellent — not just popular — I'd recommend it to everyone in my cultural orbit.

name: Nkechi Okafor
clarity_response: An app that gives you a curated shortlist of NYC activities based on what you like, when you're free, and your budget.
strongest_line: What's your budget — free only, under $20, or no limit? We filter so you don't have to.
weakest_section: The free events objection is good but I need more proof. One paragraph isn't enough — show me examples of curated free events.
what_feels_off: The free events answer is reassuring but I've heard this before. How do you actually verify quality for free events?
objections: How do you quality-control free events? Is there a rating system? Who decides what's 'actually fun'?
gut_reaction: The budget filter being upfront is exactly what I need. Most apps bury it. The fact that it's in Step 2 is a trust signal.
unanswered_questions: How do you quality-control free events? Is there a minimum quality threshold?
share_trigger: If it consistently found me quality free things to do, I'd share it with every broke friend I have. Which is all of them.

name: David Kim
clarity_response: A curated activity finder for NYC that narrows options to 3-5 personalized picks with budget filtering.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
weakest_section: Budget options are 'free only, under $20, or no limit.' Where's under $10? The jump from free to $20 is too big for me.
what_feels_off: Under $20 is still a lot when you're broke. I need an 'under $10' option. The price ranges feel designed by someone who isn't actually budget-constrained.
objections: The budget tiers are wrong. Free → $20 → unlimited? $5-$10 is my actual sweet spot. This feels designed by someone with more money.
gut_reaction: Close but the budget tiers reveal a blind spot. $20 isn't 'budget' for someone who makes $17/hour.
unanswered_questions: Can I set a custom budget? Will there be more granular price tiers?
share_trigger: If it consistently found me $0-$10 things that were actually good, I'd tell everyone at my job.

name: Hannah Kim
clarity_response: A personalized NYC events shortlist. Filters by interests, time, distance, and budget to give you 3-5 picks.
strongest_line: Stop scrolling six apps just to figure out what to do this weekend.
weakest_section: The example card is free admission. What does a $15 event card look like? I need to see how paid events are presented too.
what_feels_off: Showing only a free example might set expectations that this is a free-events-only app. I want quality at every price tier.
objections: Is this primarily a free events app or does it work well for paid events under $20 too?
gut_reaction: Finally an app that puts budget up front instead of showing me $80 events I'll never attend. The concept is respectful of my wallet.
unanswered_questions: How's the paid event curation? Is the quality filtering as good for $10-$20 events as for free ones?
share_trigger: If I could share a 'things to do this weekend under $15' shortlist with friends, that's an instant group chat link.

name: Kwame Asante
clarity_response: An NYC activity recommendation app. Gives you 3-5 curated events based on interests, schedule, location, and budget.
strongest_line: Zero rabbit holes.
weakest_section: The page is long. I got the point fast but then kept scrolling. Washington Heights isn't mentioned anywhere — feels Manhattan/Brooklyn only.
what_feels_off: The geography feels exclusive. Chelsea, Brooklyn, Midtown East — all in the quotes and examples. Upper Manhattan doesn't exist on this page.
objections: Does this work uptown? Or is this another app where everything cool is below 96th street?
dealbreaker_reason: If there's nothing for Washington Heights and Upper Manhattan, it's useless to me regardless of how good the concept is.
gut_reaction: Good idea. But it feels built for downtown Brooklyn and Manhattan. I need to believe it covers my neighborhood before signing up.
unanswered_questions: Geographic coverage? Does it include Upper Manhattan? The Bronx? Northern Brooklyn?
share_trigger: If it found me something cool in Washington Heights, I'd post about it. That never happens with NYC apps.

name: Jasmine Wright
clarity_response: A curated NYC events shortlist with budget filtering. Personalizes 3-5 picks to your interests and constraints.
strongest_line: Your weekend shouldn't take longer to plan than to enjoy.
weakest_section: The social proof quotes don't include anyone who mentions money. If cost-awareness is a feature, it should be in the testimonials.
what_feels_off: The budget filter is positioned as one of three features, but nobody in the social proof mentions cost. It feels secondary to the team.
objections: I want to see a testimonial from someone who says 'it helped me find great free things' — that's not here.
gut_reaction: The feature set speaks to me. The social proof doesn't. I want to see people like me reflected in the quotes.
unanswered_questions: Is the budget filter a first-class feature or an afterthought?
share_trigger: If the free recommendations were genuinely good, I'd share it with my mom friends who have the same budget constraint.

name: Grace Tanaka
clarity_response: An app that filters NYC activities down to a personalized shortlist of 3-5 based on interests, timing, distance, and budget.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
weakest_section: CTA asks me to 'join the waitlist' — but what do I get? A weekly email? An app invite? The ask is unclear.
what_feels_off: The waitlist offer is vague. Am I getting early access to an app? A newsletter? 'Join the waitlist' for what exactly?
objections: What does joining the waitlist actually get me? Be specific about the deliverable.
gut_reaction: The free event quality filtering is the best part. That alone would make me use this. The rest is good but that's the hook.
unanswered_questions: What does the waitlist deliver? When? Is there a free tier guaranteed?
share_trigger: If I could get a weekly 'free things worth doing' email, I'd forward it to my entire grad school cohort.

name: Leo Tran
clarity_response: A curated NYC activities shortlist. 3-5 personalized recommendations based on interests, schedule, budget, and location.
strongest_line: How far will you travel?
weakest_section: No mention of whether the app itself will cost money. If this is a paid app, that's an immediate no for my budget.
what_feels_off: The page never says whether the service is free. That's the first thing I need to know.
objections: Is this app free to use? If it costs a monthly subscription, I'm out. That should be stated upfront.
dealbreaker_reason: If the app itself costs money, I can't afford another subscription. The page's silence on pricing is concerning.
gut_reaction: Concept is good. But a budget-focused app that doesn't disclose its own pricing? That feels contradictory.
unanswered_questions: Is the app free? Will there be a paid tier? What features are gated?
share_trigger: If it's completely free and actually good, I'd share it everywhere. But I need to know the price first.

name: Camila Herrera
clarity_response: An NYC events app that gives you a shortlist of curated activities based on your preferences and budget.
strongest_line: Free stuff in NYC is usually hit or miss. You're right — it is.
weakest_section: Same as the outer-borough concern. Sunset Park isn't the kind of neighborhood NYC apps cover. Will this be different?
what_feels_off: The honesty about free events being hit-or-miss earned trust. But the Manhattan/Brooklyn-centric examples lost some of it.
objections: Outer-borough coverage. If everything is in Manhattan or Williamsburg, the distance filter won't help me — there just won't be anything nearby.
gut_reaction: The free events angle is strong. The geographic coverage question keeps me from fully committing.
unanswered_questions: Coverage in outer boroughs? Events in Sunset Park, Bay Ridge, southern Brooklyn?
share_trigger: If it found me something good and free in southern Brooklyn, I'd share that find with everyone in my neighborhood.

name: Leah Goldstein
clarity_response: A filtered NYC events list. Gives you 3-5 picks based on what you like and your budget.
strongest_line: What's your budget — free only, under $20, or no limit?
weakest_section: The page is optimized for individuals. My problem is coordinating with friends who have different budgets. Can it handle a group with mixed price tolerance?
what_feels_off: Individual-focused. My reality is: I'm broke, my friend makes six figures. We need something we can do together that works for both budgets.
objections: No group-budget feature. I need 'activities that work for mixed-income friend groups.' That's my real problem.
gut_reaction: Addresses half my problem. The budget filter is good. The group coordination part is missing entirely.
unanswered_questions: Group features? Mixed-budget group filtering?
share_trigger: If I could send my rich friend and my broke friend the same shortlist and it worked for both, that's a miracle worth sharing.

name: Carlos Mendez
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity shortlist app. 3-5 curated picks based on interests, schedule, budget, and distance.
strongest_line: Outdoor activities & day trips (in the category list).
weakest_section: Categories mention 'outdoor activities' but the whole page, example, and vibe is indoor/urban. Where's the outdoor proof?
what_feels_off: Outdoor activities listed but not demonstrated. The example is an art gallery. Show me a free outdoor event.
objections: Is the outdoor coverage real or just a listed category? I want hiking, park events, outdoor fitness, beach stuff.
gut_reaction: I like that outdoor is listed. I'm skeptical it's actually built out. Show me an outdoor event card.
unanswered_questions: How deep is the outdoor/nature category? Day trips? Parks? Outdoor fitness?
share_trigger: If it found me free outdoor events in Brooklyn parks I didn't know about, I'd share that with my hiking friends.

name: Maya Chen
clarity_response: A curated NYC events app. Filters activities to a shortlist based on preferences and budget, with an emphasis on quality free events.
strongest_line: You'll see what's genuinely worth showing up to, not just what costs $0.
weakest_section: Inwood is never going to be covered by this. The neighborhoods referenced are all below 125th street. This is a recurring pattern with NYC apps.
what_feels_off: Beautiful concept. But Inwood, Washington Heights, the Bronx — we exist too. The geographic bias is showing.
objections: Geographic coverage is my biggest concern. If this is another Williamsburg-to-Tribeca app, I'm excluded.
dealbreaker_reason: If Inwood and Upper Manhattan aren't covered, this product isn't for me. And the page gives me no confidence they will be.
gut_reaction: I love the free events quality filter. Hate that I'm probably not in the coverage area. Story of every NYC app.
unanswered_questions: Does this cover above 125th street? Inwood? The Bronx?
share_trigger: If it covered Inwood events and free uptown programming, I'd spread it through my entire neighborhood community.

name: Isabel Torres
clarity_response: An events recommendation app for NYC. Budget filter, personalized shortlist of 3-5.
strongest_line: Free only, under $20, or no limit.
weakest_section: Everything. I've heard this pitch before. ClassPass said similar things. Fever said similar things. What makes this different?
what_feels_off: Nothing is new here. Filter by budget + interest + location = every event app ever. The shortlist angle is the only differentiator and it's not enough.
objections: I need evidence this works differently. The pitch is familiar. 'We curate' is what every platform says.
dealbreaker_reason: No evidence of actual differentiation from existing platforms I've already tried and abandoned.
gut_reaction: Skeptical. Sounds good in theory. So did every other event app that's now dead. Show me the product.
unanswered_questions: How is this actually different from existing apps? What's the retention rate? Why will this survive when others didn't?
share_trigger: Only if it actually delivered consistently better results than what I already use. Which I'll believe when I see it.
